questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below shows transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The histopathology specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Women present with menorrhagia, progressively increasing dysmenorrhea, pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia. Clinical examination revealinf a painful, symmetrical enlargementy of the uterus should suggest adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include the salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance (shown in the image below). 

MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

questions.text: A patient who stopped alcohol consumption 48 hours back presented with irritability, tremors, disorientation, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. His heart rate is 160 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 170/80 mm of Hg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 48 hours presenting with disorientation, agitation, visual hallucinations, altered sensorium, tachycardia, and elevated blood pressure is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by symptoms such as:

  • Extreme mental confusion
  • Agitation
  • Tremors
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, sweating, insomnia, and hypertension

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. It is associated with a triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is associated with anterograde and retrograde amnesia. Confabulation is a classic sign.

Option D - Alcoholic hallucinosis occurs during heavy drinking or withdrawal and is characterized by paranoid psychosis without other symptoms such as tremulousness, confusion, and altered sensorium.

questions.text: A newborn is having a cataract and murmur on auscultation. Mother had viral exanthem in the pregnancy period. What we can expect in this child?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella.

Incidence of heart diseases in congenital rubella : PDA > PS > VSD > ASD

Related Pearl: Congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome

The triad of congenital rubella syndrome (Gregg's triad) includes:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss: Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease: The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus.

Blueberry muffin rash : Reddish-blue widespread maculopapular rash which may be present at birth or appear during infancy. 

Diagnosis: Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months. 

Image: Bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan’s pulse, is characterized by a sharp rise and a rapid fall-off and is seen in aortic regurgitation.

The water hammer pulse is appreciated by raising the arm rapidly and assessing the characteristics of the radial pulse. It is speculated to arise from the rapid ejection of a large left ventricular stroke volume into a low resistance arterial system.

questions.text: A middle age male patient with a long history of poorly controlled hypertension presents for a follow-up. The physician prescribes a doppler ultrasonography which reveals severe stenosis of the right renal artery due to atherosclerosis. Which of the following drugs is recommended for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is unilateral renal artery stenosis. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors(ACEi) such as enalapril are used in the management of patients with unilateral renal artery stenosis.

Patients with renal artery stenosis present with refractory/new-onset hypertension. Physical examination may reveal an audible bruit on the affected side in these patients. Doppler ultrasonography or CT angiography can be used to confirm a diagnosis of renal artery stenosis. Renal angiography is the gold standard investigation.

Treatment options are:

  • Medical management with ACEi
  • Angioplasty with or without stenting
  • Surgical bypass

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure and hence contraindicated.

questions.text: A young cricketer presented with severe pain and deformity of the shoulder following bowling practice. The AP-view radiograph of the affected shoulder is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bankart lesion may occur as a complication
Recurrence is associated with Hill-Sachs lesion
Radial nerve is most commonly injured
It can also be caused by a fall on the hand

questions.solution:
This radiograph shows anterior dislocation of the shoulder. The nerve commonly injured in anterior dislocation is the axillary nerve, not the radial nerve. 

The radiograph shows the disturbed articulation between the humeral head and glenoid fossa. The humeral head is seen below and medial to the glenoid socket. This suggests anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint. 

Common cause for anterior dislocation:

  • Young adults - athletic injuries
  • Elderly - falls (Option D)

Complications include:

  • Bankart lesion (Option A) is a tear in the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum caused by the head of the humerus during anterior dislocation. 
  • Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head in recurrent dislocations. (Option B)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh presents with the following lesions on his teeth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image along with the endemic area of Andhra Pradesh is diagnostic of Dental fluorosis.

Dental fluorosis (also termed mottled enamel) is an extremely common disorder, characterized by hypomineralization of tooth enamel caused by ingestion of excessive fluoride during enamel formation.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Mechanism:

  • In the extra-cellular environment of maturing enamel, an excess of fluoride ions alters the rate at which enamel matrix proteins (amelogenin) are enzymatically broken down and the rate at which the subsequent breakdown products are removed.
  • Fluoride may also indirectly alter the action of protease via a decrease in the availability of free calcium ions in the mineralization environment.
  • This results in the formation of enamel with less mineralization.
  • This hypomineralized enamel has altered optical properties and appears opaque and lustreless relative to normal enamel.

Classification:

The two main classification systems which are used in the grading of severity of dental fluorosis are Dean’s system and TF system.

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. Best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in a water treatment plant can be moderately expensive. The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child?

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.solution:
The child, in this scenario, has some degree of dehydration since the child is restless and irritable, drinks water readily, shows slow retraction(<2 seconds) of skin on skin pinch test, and has sunken eyes. Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) protocol plan B.

WHO IMNCI PLANS:

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman had her routine follow up and her USG of the liver is shown below. She is asymptomatic at present but has a history of mild right hypochondriac pain which is relieved by taking analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The USG shows a gallbladder wall that is thickened with no edema in the pericholecystic fat. The gallbladder contains biliary sludge and gallstones, shown as the acoustic shadowing. There are no signs of current cholecystitis and thus the diagnosis is gallstones.

Ultrasonography is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. They appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. Size of the gallbladder, presence of stones or polyps, and the thickness of the wall are measured. Inflammation around the gallbladder, the size of the common bile duct, and stones in the extrahepatic biliary tree can also be determined. The sensitivity of UG is > 95%. Small stones can be differentiated from small polyps by the presence of mobility or of an acoustic shadow. 

The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder:  

Amoebic liver abscess ( Option b)  shows necrotic material and debris on usg without any acoustic shadows. Diagnosis is often found using aspiration.

 

Hydatid cysts (option c) can present similarly. There is tenderness and enlargement of the liver with blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes. USG can show various stages, classical being multiple septations and rosette or honeycomb appearance, Water Lilly sign when the cyst wall detaches

The image below shows the multiple septations in ultrasonography of hydatid cyst.

An ultrasound scan in acute cholecystitis (Option d ) demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thickened wall of >3 mm, pericholecystic fluid, the presence of gallstone( when it is due to associated cholelithiasis), and the sonographic Murphy's sign. Gallbladder distension (diameter >5 cm), pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall striations, and, occasionally, wall hyperemia on Doppler examination may also be seen in USG.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with seizures, intellectual disability, and subependymal nodules on the MRI brain. On examination, the following cutaneous lesion is seen. Name the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the image shows ash leaf macules seen in this condition.

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the presence of benign congenital tumors in multiple organs. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. Loss-of-function mutations of these tumour suppressor genes (TSC1&2) are present. It presents during childhood with intellectual disability, skin lesions, and seizures. On brain MRI, subependymal nodules can be seen.

The clinical features include seizures, intellectual disability, white ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs. Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), a shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin‐coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region. Periungual fibromas and renal angiomyolipomas

Various skin lesions seen in tuberous sclerosis are:

Facial angiofibromas(Option A) - reddish nodules seen on the nose and cheeks. Eventually, they join together to form a fleshy growth. It is shown in the image given below:

Periungual fibromas - They are small fibromas or skin nodules seen around fingers or toenails in a few patients. The image below shows these lesions:

A Shagreen patch(Option D) is a rough, raised lesion commonly seen in the lumbosacral region.

Ash leaf macules - hypomelanotic macules that are ≥5 mm, seen on the trunk and extremities as shown in the image below:

Confetti skin lesions(Option B) are hypomelanotic macules that are 1-3 mm in diameter.

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign being elicited in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The clinical sign being elicited is Fluid thrill.

The fluid thrill is elicited to clinically diagnose ascites.

It is not a reliable sign and is only felt when there is a large amount of fluid under tension.

Method: The patient is placed supine and his abdomen is exposed after consent. Place one hand of the examiner flat over the lumbar region while an assistant's hand is kept firmly on the midline of the abdomen with the side of his hand kept longitudinally. This is done to dampen any impulse that can be transmitted via the fat of the abdominal wall. Now the examiner flicks or taps the opposite side of the abdomen where his palm is not resting and a fluid thrill or wave is felt on the resting hand.

Clinical signs associated with ascites:

Finding Minimum volume(ml)
Puddle sign positive 120 
Shifting dullness 500
Fluid thrill 1500 

Note:

The cardinal clinical sign for ascites is shifting dullness.

questions.text: The cystographic appearance shown below is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Christmas tree bladder or pine cone bladder is a cystogram appearance which usually seen in severe neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone.

  • A pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder is a cystogram appearance in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall.
  • It is typically seen in (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or epiconal lesions (in and around S2-S4).
  • Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.
  • This finding is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It can also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: All of the following are used to monitor systemic perfusion in shock except?
questions.solution:
Base deficit, lactate, and mixed venous oxygen saturation are used to monitor systemic perfusion in patients with shock. Tissue oxygen electrode, as the name implies, is used to monitor organ perfusion in muscles and the brain.

The goal of treatment in shock resuscitation is to restore cellular and organ perfusion and therefore, monitoring of organ perfusion should guide the management of shock. The best clinical measure of organ perfusion and best monitor of the adequacy of shock therapy is urine output. However, this is an hourly measure and does not give a minute ­to­ minute view of the shocked state. The level of consciousness is another clinical marker of cerebral perfusion, but brain perfusion is maintained until the very late stages of shock. It is a poor marker of the adequacy of resuscitation. 

Investigation monitors that can be used for systemic perfusion are base deficit, lactate, and mixed venous oxygen saturation. The degree of lactic acidosis is sensitive for both diagnosis of shock and monitoring the response to therapy. It is measured by serum lactate level and/or the base deficit. A base deficit of more than 6 mmol/L indicates much higher morbidity and mortality likelihood than in those with no metabolic acidosis. 

The percentage saturation of oxygen returning to the heart from the body reflects the oxygen delivery and extraction by the tissues. Samples may be drawn from a long central line placed in the right atrium or lines in the superior vena cava. Mixed venous oxygen saturation levels below 50% indicate inadequate oxygen delivery and increased oxygen extraction by the cells which is consistent with hypovolaemic or cardiogenic shock. High mixed venous saturations (>70%) can be seen in sepsis and other forms of distributive shock.

Specific investigational monitors of organ perfusion are as follows:

  • Muscle and brain: Near-infrared spectroscopy and tissue oxygen electrode
  • Gut: Sublingual capnometry, gut mucosal pH, and laser Doppler flowmetry

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for female with atrophic vaginitis with complains of itching?
questions.solution:
Atrophic vaginitis is treated with topical estrogen vaginal cream.

Use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally each day for 1 to 2 weeks generally provides relief. Systemic estrogen therapy should be considered to prevent recurrence of this disorder.

questions.text: You are the medical officer responsible for seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

choices.text: Used in patients with unexplained genital bleeding
Contraindicated in patients with large fibroids
Contraindicated in patients with pelvic inflammatory disease

questions.solution:
The image shows types of copper-based intrauterine devices. Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) are contraindicated in patients with unexplained genital bleeding.

Copper T is a type of IUCD that utilizes the local antifertility effect of copper ions. They provide a long-term, reversible method of contraception. IUCDs are contraindicated in the following situations:

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Patients who have signs and symptoms of infection following delivery or abortion
  • Malignancy-malignant trophoblastic disease, cervical, endometrial, or uterine cancer
  • Anatomical abnormalities of the uterine tract or fibroids that distort the shape of the uterine cavity
  • Pelvic tuberculosis
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Current pelvic inflammatory disease, purulent cervicitis, Chlamydia, or gonorrheal infection
  • Wilson's disease and copper allergy are additional contraindications to the use of copper-based IUCDs

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. What is the initial treatment of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors and diuretics

questions.solution:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and diuretics are the first-line treatment in patients with heart failure and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction.

This is usually followed by the addition of a beta blocker once there is adequate diuresis.

Note: SGLT2 inhibitors such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin have shown a significant decrease in morbidity and mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

questions.text: A patient is undergoing parotidectomy. Which of the following measures reduces the risk of the development of Frey's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Frey's syndrome or gustatory sweating occurs as a result of aberrant innervation of the dermal sweat glands by the regenerating fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve following parotid surgery. This can be prevented intraoperatively by placing a temporalis fascia flap between the skin and the parotid bed.

Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food. The diagnosis can be confirmed with Minor's starch-iodine test. This test involves applying iodine and dry starch over the suspected area, and giving a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue.

Frey's syndrome occurs as a consequence of parotidectomy in most patients but is usually not significant. It can be prevented by the following methods:

  • Raising a thick flap (including the subcutaneous tissue) over the parotid
  • Interposition of tissues such as sternocleidomastoid flap, temporalis fascia or autologous fat between the skin and the surgical bed
  • Extracapsular dissection of parotid gland for benign pathologies

Treatment of established Frey's syndrome involves the use of anti-perpirants, botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin, and neurectomy of the Jacobson's nerve, which forms the tympanic plexus and gives the pre-ganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion, in the form of lesser petrosal nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple episodes of vomiting. Which of the following laboratory results would be seen in his arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is lost due to vomiting. Loss of HCl results in HCO3− generation causing metabolic alkalosis. Among the given options, high pH (7.55) and high HCO3- (30 mEq/L) are suggestive of metabolic alkalosis. A high pCO2 (48 mmHg) represents respiratory acidosis as a result of compensatory hypoventilation.

Hypochloremia occurs because of loss of HCl during vomiting and is maintained due to loss of Cl- in the kidney which accompanies increased HCO3-reabsorption

Multiple episodes of vomiting result in loss of acids from the body and thus increases the pH.

questions.text: A G2P1 female with 5 months of gestation comes to the OPD with complaints of swelling of both feet. On examination, her BP is 130/90 mmHg and she has bilateral pedal edema. What is the appropriate treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bed rest is the appropriate treatment for women having edema in pregnancy.

The cause of physiological edema is due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.

Features of the physiological edema:

  • Slight degree (ankle edema)
  • Usually confined to one leg, more on the right
  • Unassociated with any other features of preeclampsia or proteinuria
  • Disappears on rest alone
  • Other pathologies of cardiac, renal and hematological are absent.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised?
questions.solution:
The final switch to heparin in pregnant women is advised at 36 weeks of pregnancy.

The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin (Unfractionated heparin-UFH): It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH (low molecular weight heparin): Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously.

questions.text: A young female patient with a history of several episodes of bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency ward after she was found in a state of distress with several empty bottles of her medication. On examination, she appears confused, and agitated and has coarse tremors, ataxia, and hyperreflexia. Which of the following drugs is likely to have caused her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of bipolar disorder along with central nervous symptoms such as confusion, agitation, coarse tremors, ataxia, and hyperreflexia point toward a possible diagnosis of lithium toxicity.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is used in the treatment of acute mania and bipolar disorder.

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is necessary for patients who are on lithium therapy.

0.5-0.8 mEq/L is considered ideal for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder whereas a serum lithium concentration of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L is required in patients with episodes of acute mania.

Initially, lithium toxicity presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, mild diarrhea, and fine tremors. Nervous system toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, ataxia, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Which of the following is seen with cannabis usage?
questions.solution:
Amotivation syndrome and flashback phenomenon are seen with cannabis usage.

Amotivation syndrome:

It is characterized by a person's unwillingness to perform a task in school/at work that requires prolonged attention. It is mostly seen with chronic usage of cannabis. Person with amotivation syndrome is usually described as apathetic, anergic, usually gaining weight and appearing slothful

Flashback phenomenon:

Person experience sensations related to substance intoxication after the short-term effects of the substance have disappeared. That is person relives the substance(cannabis) use experience without consuming it.

Flashback phenomenon is also seen in Lysergic acid diethylamide(LSD), phencyclidine whch are hallucinogens.

questions.text: A woman presents with complaints of greenish frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. On speculum examination, you are able to see the below finding. This is associated with
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is suggestive of a strawberry cervix. It is seen in trichomoniasis

The clinical features include vaginal discharge which is profuse, thin, slightly green in color, and frothy. It may be associated with vaginal irritation, dysuria, and increased frequency. Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots known as the strawberry cervix is typically seen in trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Motile trichomonads are seen on wet mount examination.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV hypertrophy. A doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, can lead to vasodilation and may reduce preload. This reduction in preload can exacerbate the obstruction in the left ventricular outflow tract, worsening the symptoms in some patients with HOCM.

Smaller chamber size and increased contractility exacerbate the severity of obstruction. These include conditions of low preload, such as dehydration, and low afterload, such as arterial vasodilation.

Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and thus contraindicated in HCM are:

  • Digoxin
  • Inotropes
  • Nitrates
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine)

Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM. Disopyramide and amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.

questions.text: If histopathological examination of a 2-day-old forearm laceration is done, which of the following would be seen?
questions.solution:
Neutrophil peak is seen on day 2 of the inflammatory phase of wound healing.

Wound healing has three phases: The inflammatory phase, proliferative phase, and maturation phase. The inflammatory phase lasts 2-3 days.

Wound healing has 3 phases. The first phase is marked by hemostasis and inflammation. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN)s are the first infiltrating cells to enter the wound site, peaking at 24 to 48 hours. The second population of inflammatory cells that invade the wound are macrophages which peak in 48-96 hours. T lymphocytes routinely invade the wound and peak at about 1-week postinjury and truly bridge the transition from the inflammatory to the proliferative phase of healing.

The second phase of proliferation roughly spans days 4-12 days. Fibroblasts and endothelial cells are the last cell populations to infiltrate the healing wound. The strongest chemotactic factor for fibroblasts is PDGF (Platelet-derived growth factor).

The third phase is characterized by the maturation and remodeling of the scar which involves reorganization of previously synthesized collagen.

The phases of wound healing and the levels of infiltrating cells are represented in the graph below.

questions.text: An elderly man is brought to the hospital after he complained of sudden jerky movements of his hands, which persist even when he is asleep. There is also a history of impaired memory. He underwent a corneal transplant 3 years ago. His electroencephalogram showed periodic slow sharp waves. His MRI scan is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows the presence of cortical ribboning. This finding, along with the presence of dementia, periodic slow sharp waves on the electroencephalogram, and myoclonic jerks are suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (HGH) preparations.

Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic electrical bursts. MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.

The image below shows the presence of periodic electrical bursts of triphasic sharp waves on the electroencephalogram of a patient with CJD:

The given image shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning in a CJD patient:

 Other options:

Option A- Sturge Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomas of the leptomeninges and in the ophthalmic and maxillary nerve areas of distribution. Affected patients might have developmental delays, learning difficulties, and seizures. CT shows the presence of a tram track appearance.

Option C- Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive demyelinating disease of the brain that occurs due to a previous infection with the measles virus. Most patients have a history of measles infection from many years ago. SSPE presents with intellectual disability, poor school performance, and mood and personality changes. EEG shows high voltage slow sharp waves that occur every 3-8 seconds followed by a flat background.

Option D- Patients with tuberous sclerosis present with seizures, mental retardation, adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), shagreen patch, hypomelanotic macules, periungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipomas, cardiac rhabdomyomas. Imaging may show the presence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following clinical features is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with a distended abdomen, poor feeding and exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months points to the diagnosis of Kwashiorkor. Flaky paint dermatosis is seen in this condition.

The skin abnormalities include increased pigmentation, shedding of skin cells, and dyspigmentation. The pigmentation may appear as overlapping patches resembling peeling paint.

Skin changes typically occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath that are easily infected, known as flaky paint dermatosis.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema. The edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs. It quickly develops into generalized edema affecting also the hands, arms, and face (moon face). 

The hair is sparse and easily pulled out and may lose its curl. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish, with alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand, known as flag sign. Children with edema are apathetic and often refuse to eat.

Other options: Simian facies, loose wrinkled skin, baggy pant appearance, and alert child with no edema are characteristic features of marasmus.

Given below is the image of a marasmic patient with its characteristic appearance

questions.text: The below picture depicts ______
questions.solution:
The above picture depicts placenta with two lobes, hence the answer is placenta succenturiata.

Succenturiate Placenta

  • The second lobe is also known as the accessory lobe. 
  • Accessory lobe is attached to main lobe by membrane which has leash of blood vessels. 
  • A placenta containing three or more equally sized lobes is rare and termed multilobate.

Complication

  • Accessory lobe can be retained causing subinvolution, sepsis, Post-partum haemorrhage, vasa previa, fetal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of food, which is followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting is bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

The weight is normal in most patients with bulimia nervosa. However, few patients may either be overweight or underweight. There is a risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. 

Treatment modalities are cognitive behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and antidepressants such as fluoxetine.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese. These symptoms are usually present for at least a period of 3 months. Associated features can include depression, anxiety, amenorrhea in females, hypothermia, and bradycardia. 

Option C: Atypical depression is a type of depression characterized by mood reactivity, which is brightening of the mood in response to positive events; significant weight gain or increase in appetite; hypersomnia; leaden paralysis; and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity, resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment. 

Option D: Binge-eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is characterized by rapid intake of abnormally large quantities of food over a short period of time, even when not hungry. There are feelings of guilt about the eating episodes, but these patients do not compensate in any way following the episodes of binge.

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders

questions.text: A patient with a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His radiograph images are given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is chronic osteomyelitis.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accidents). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare-up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

Necrosis of healthy tissue is an important feature of osteomyelitis. In patients with osteomyelitis, dead cortical bone gets separated from the healthy bone and can be visualized clearly on plain radiographs. This dead bone is termed a sequestrum.

The given image shows an oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum, known as involucrum. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Option A: Osteogenic sarcoma characteristically shows the sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, as shown below.

 Option B: Ewing's sarcoma shows an onion-skin appearance of the periosteum, as shown below.

 Option D: Multiple myeloma shows multiple punched-out lesions of the bone, as shown below.

questions.text: A young girl presented to the outpatient department with pallor of extremities, pain, and cyanosis on exposure to cold. This phenomenon is commonly associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above clinical scenario is likely describing Raynaud's phenomenon. Raynaud's phenomenon is usually an initial manifestation of scleroderma.

Raynaud phenomenon presents as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in most cases.

The image shows features of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Systemic sclerosis is characterized by progressive fibrosis involving the skin and internal organs. Two forms of this disease are limited and diffuse. Limited systemic sclerosis is also associated with one or more features of CREST syndrome. CREST syndrome is:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Esophageal motility disorder
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came to the hospital for medical termination of pregnancy. From whom will you obtain consent for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Only the patient's consent is required for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) and her male partner's consent is not required.

Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side and soft and the hard palate are intact. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam).

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 5–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: A patient presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. On KOH mount, spaghetti and meatballs appearance is noted. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The characteristic appearance of ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes' on KOH mount and microscopy (shown below) is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous).

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. Versicolor: Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species.

Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is another characteristic finding of tinea versicolor. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign.

Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Option A: Tinea cruris, also known as jock itch, is a dermatophyte infection affecting the inguinal folds, which may extend to the vulva and perianal area. 

Option B:  Tinea capitis, also known as scalp ringworm, is a fungal infection affecting the scalp. 

Option C: Tinea corporis, is a fungal infection, which can occur anywhere in the body, with the classical ring shaped/annular rash. 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Vitiligo

questions.text: A female patient who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the presence of multiple, linear, irregular filling defects on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of scar tissue in the endometrial cavity.

It refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Patients present with features such as oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, and synechiae due to uterine adhesions.

The following factors predispose a patient to develop Asherman syndrome:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum hemorrhage or abortion
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Schistosomiasis

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common antecedent infectious cause of Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Campylobacter jejuni is one of the most common risk factors for GBS.

Infections that may trigger GBS are:

  • Campylobacter jejuni 
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Epstein Barr virus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Varicella zoster virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza, Zika, hepatitis

Less commonly vaccinations, surgical procedures, and trauma have been reported to trigger the development of GBS.

questions.text: The diagnostic test with the highest sensitivity to diagnose chronic pancreatitis is:
questions.solution:
The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity for chronic pancreatitis is the secretin test.

Secretin is a hormone secreted by the small intestines. It normally stimulates the pancreas to secrete a fluid with a high concentration of bicarbonate. The secretin stimulation test is a test that measures the ability of the pancreas to respond to secretin.

In order to perform the test, a tube is passed into the duodenum. Secretin is administered intravenously and the contents of the duodenal secretions are aspirated and analyzed over a period of about 2 hours. The test becomes abnormal when ≥60% of the pancreatic exocrine function has been lost. This usually correlates well with the onset of chronic abdominal pain. 

Other investigations to diagnose chronic pancreatitis:

Pancreatic calcifications can be seen on abdominal X-rays.

Endoscopic ultrasound showing the presence of four or more of these following features is highly suggestive of chronic pancreatitis:

  • Presence of stones
  • Visible side branches
  • Cysts
  • Lobularity
  • An irregular main pancreatic duct
  • Hyperechoic foci and strands
  • Dilatation of the main pancreatic duct
  • Hyperechoic margins of the main pancreatic duct

An abdominal CT scan is the initial modality of choice for diagnosing chronic pancreatitis. CT or MRI scan will show the outline of the gland, the main area of damage, and the possibilities for surgical correction.
The investigation of choice for chronic pancreatitis is MRCP with secretin stimulation.

ERCP is the gold-standard investigation. They help in identifying the presence of biliary obstruction and the state of the pancreatic duct.

questions.text: Which is the shortest acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (succinyl choline) is the shortest acting muscle relaxant.

It has a rapid onset (30–60 s) and short duration of action (typically less than 10 min) due to rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (aka plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase).

Other options:

  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It has an intermediate duration of action, which means it lasts longer than Suxamethonium but shorter than some other muscle relaxants like Pancuronium. Vecuronium is often used in surgical settings to provide muscle relaxation and facilitate intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • Pancuronium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It has a longer duration of action compared to Vecuronium, making it a medium-acting muscle relaxant. Pancuronium is used for muscle relaxation during surgery and mechanical ventilation but has a longer-lasting effect compared to Suxamethonium.
  • Pipecuronium is another non-depolarizing muscle relaxant with an intermediate duration of action, similar to Vecuronium. It is used in clinical settings for muscle relaxation during surgery or other procedures that require controlled muscle paralysis.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after spilling hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple blisters are present on his right hand. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and capillary refilling is normal.  Which layers of skin are involved in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and normal capillary refilling time has second-degree superficial burns. The layers of skin involved here are the epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis).

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9
