questions.text: Central pontine myelinolysis is caused by  ______
questions.solution:
Rapid correction of hyponatremia may result in central pontine myelinolysis.

Central pontine myelinolysis is an osmotic demyelination syndrome, wherein rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells.

When a person with severe hyponatremia receives treatment to rapidly increase their blood sodium levels, it can disrupt the osmotic balance in the brain. The brain cells have adapted to the lower sodium levels, and rapid correction can lead to the movement of water out of these cells, causing them to shrink and damage the myelin sheath, which is the protective covering of nerve fibers in the central pontine region of the brain. This demyelination can result in the characteristic neurological symptoms of CPM.

The condition is often seen in individuals with severe, chronic hyponatremia, such as in alcoholics or people with certain medical conditions.

It is characterized by the acute onset of quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with complaints of long-standing swelling of the left leg as shown in the image. The swelling disappears in the morning and on examination, pitting is seen. What grade of lymphedema is this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, pitting edema which disappears completely on elevation and bed rest indicates grade I lymphedema, according to Brunner's classification.

Clinical classification of lymphedema:

Grade (Brunner)

Clinical features

Subclinical

There is excessive interstitial fluid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes, but no clinically apparent lymphedema.

Grade I

Edema pits on pressure and the swelling completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.

Grade II

Edema does not pit and does not significantly reduce on elevation, positive Stemmer’s sign

Grade III

Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes i.e. fibrosis and papillae.

questions.text: A 42-year-old  daily wage laborer comes to you with discoloration of her legs. She was diagnosed with varicose veins 5 years ago which was left untreated. Identify the feature given in the picture.
questions.solution:
Atrophia blanche is localised white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankles. This is a sign of chronic venous disease.

Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to 'inverted champagne bottle' appearance.

 

Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

questions.text: Whipple’s triad is seen in which of the following diseases:
questions.solution:
Whipple’s triad is seen in patients with insulinoma.

It consists of the following three features:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia
  • Low plasma glucose levels at the time of symptoms
  • Reversal of hypoglycemic symptoms with ingestion of carbohydrates within 15 minutes

Whipple’s disease – Malabsorption by Tropheryma whippeli

Whipple’s operation – Carcinoma pancreas

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called as lead time.

Other options:

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text:
Choose the correctly matched pairs.

1. Delusion of grandeur

2. Delusion of infidelity

3. Delusion of love 

4. Nihilistic delusion 

i. Othello syndrome

ii. Cotard syndrome

iii. De Clerambault syndrome

iv. Megalomania
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

1. Delusion of grandeur

iv. Megalomania

2. Delusion of infidelity

i. Othello syndrome
3. Delusion of love

iii. De Clerambault syndrome
4. Nihilistic delusion

ii. Cotard syndrome

 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Which of the following events in Rh-negative patients does not require Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis.

Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances:

  • Pregnancy loss due to:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole
    • Elective abortion
    • Fetal death (any trimester)
  • Procedures:
    • Amniocentesis
    • Chorionic villus sampling
    • Fetal blood sampling
    • External cephalic version
  • Delivery
  • Trauma
  • Placental abruption
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy

questions.text:
A 24-year-old mother was diagnosed with temporary urinary retention. Which of the following are causes for this condition?

1. Episiotomy
2. Epidural anesthesia
3. Forceps delivery
4. Ventouse delivery
5. Birth weight <4 kg
questions.solution:
Causes of temporary urinary retention:

  • Episiotomy
  • Epidural anesthesia
  • Forceps delivery
  • Ventouse delivery
  • Perineal laceration
  • Birth weight >4 kg

questions.text: A young child requires inhaled corticosteroids. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following statement is not true about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the amount of drug entering the lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Can be used in small children

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a spacer.

It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other local adverse effects associated with inhaled corticosteroid use.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a metered dose inhaler.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of hemoptysis, vaginal bleeding, and abdominal pain for 7 days. Chest X-ray is shown below. Transabdominal USG revealed a solid mass occupying the uterus which was found to be choriocarcinoma with a WHO score of 8. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of high-risk (WHO) stage III choriocarcinoma which is treated with EMA-CO regimen. The given X-ray shows numerous, dense, bilateral metastatic nodules, of varying sizes indicative of lung metastases.

The components of EMA-CO are:

  • Etoposide
  • Methotrexate
  • Actinomycin D
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Oncovin i.e. vincristine
Risk Criteria Treatment
Low
  • FIGO stage I GTN
  • FIGO Stage II or III GTN with a WHO risk score <6
 Single agent chemotherapy with Methotrextate or Actinomycin D.
High
  • Stages II and III with WHO risk score >7
  • Stage IV disease

EMA-CO regimen

Option A: PSTT (placental-site trophoblastic tumor) and ETT (epithelioid trophoblastic tumors) are treated by hysterectomy only, as they are resistant to chemotherapy.

Option B: R-CHOP regimen is used for B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of taking medications for asthma, now presents with obesity, short stature, round face, and abdominal striae. What could be the most common cause of the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The probable cause, in this case, is Exogenous glucocorticoids.

History of asthma suggests that patient had been on exogenous steroids (inhaled/systemic) for long term management of severe asthma. The presenting features with a round face (moon facies), short stature, along with obesity and purple skin striae suggest a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome and the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids. History of asthma suggests, the patient was administered long term exogenous (inhaled/systemic) steroids.

Cushing's syndrome is characterized by clinical features that result from chronic exposure of excess glucocorticoids that can be due to

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids (Iatrogenic: Most common cause of Cushing's syndrome) 
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features in children

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A patient presents with a 2.5 cm swelling on her neck. The swelling is firm, non-tender, and moves on swallowing. TSH, T3, and T4 levels are normal. An ultrasound reports the swelling to be cystic and regular with low suspicion for malignancy. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform an fine needle aspiration biopsy
Reassure the patient and monitor periodically

questions.solution:
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy needs to be performed for further evaluation of the nodule.

In cases where the FNAC is inconclusive, tru-cut or open biopsy can be done. However, this is rarely required.

questions.text: In a patient requiring invasive BP monitoring, which is the preferred artery used for canulation and measurement?
questions.solution:
Radial artery is the preferred artery for invasive blood pressure monitoring because of ease of cannulation, presence of collateral blood flow and less associated complications.

Before cannulating the radial artery, it is essential to perform a modified Allen’s test in order to determine the adequacy of collateral flow to the hand.

The other arteries which can be used for invasive blood pressure monitoring are ulnar, brachial, axillary, and femoral arteries and less commonly dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, and superficial temporal arteries.

questions.text: The earliest hematological response to iron therapy in iron-deficiency anemia is _________.
questions.solution:
Bone marrow erythroid hyperplasia is the earliest hematological response to iron therapy in iron-deficiency anemia.

Responses to Iron Therapy in Iron-Deficiency Anemia:

Time after administration Response
12 to 24 h Subjective improvement- decreased
irritability, increased appetite
36 to 48 h Bone marrow response- erythroid
hyperplasia
48 to 72 h (peaks at 5-7 days) Reticulocytosis
4 to 30 days Increase in hemoglobin level
1 to 3 months Repletion of stores (ferritin)

questions.text: A primigravida patient at 26 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with acute appendicitis. what is the best step of management for this patient?

choices.text: Laparoscopic appendicectomy before 28 weeks of gestation
Conservative management till term and operate after delivery
Laparoscopic appendicectomy after 28 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The best step of management for this patient with acute appendicitis is laparoscopic appendicectomy before 28 weeks of gestation. In cases of appendicitis in pregnancy, once the diagnosis is suspected, it is essential to operate at the earliest, than to wait, as there is a risk of developing generalized peritonitis.

Acute appendicitis is the most common surgical non-gynecological cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy.

The diagnosis of acute appendicitis in pregnancy is difficult due to the following factors:

  • Nausea and vomiting may be considered normal, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy
  • Leukocytosis is a physiological finding in pregnancy
  • A gravid enlarging uterus can push the appendix upward and outward, causing the pain to localize in the right flank or right upper quadrant.

Acute appendicitis in pregnancy is associated with miscarriage, preterm delivery, increased risk of peritonitis, perinatal and maternal mortality.

USG abdomen is used to confirm. USG abdomen would reveal a >6mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated appendix seen as a blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum. MRI abdomen can be done if USG is inconclusive. Operative laparotomy with minimal uterine manipulation should be done at the earliest. Laparoscopic appendicectomy can be done before 28 weeks of gestation. Intraoperative fetal monitoring should be considered.

questions.text: All the following are notifiable occupational diseases under the Factories act except ____________.
questions.solution:
Bagassosis is not a notifiable disease.

Related Pearl: Notifiable occupational diseases

 

There are 29 diseases notifiable to the government under Indian Factory Act 1948, some important ones are

  • Byssinosis
  • Asbestosis
  • Anthracosis
  • Noise induced hearing loss
  • Occupational dermatitis
  • Occupational cancers
  • Silicosis

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in function of neutrophils that includes adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of cord, which is usually associated with infection of cord stump.

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: A patient in the post-operative ward is poorly compliant with the respiratory exercises and ends up developing respiratory failure as a result. What type of respiratory failure would this be classified as?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause of acute respiratory failure in this post-operative patient would be postoperative atelectasis. Postoperative atelectasis causes type 3 respiratory failure.

Type III respiratory failure

  • Results from lung atelectasis.
  • Since atelectasis occurs commonly in the perioperative period, this form is also called perioperative respiratory failure.
  • After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.
  • Treated by
    • Frequent changes in position
    • Chest physiotherapy
    • Upright positioning
    • Control of incisional and/or abdominal pain
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation - used to reverse regional atelectasis

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Sepsis, gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. Drug overdose, brainstem injury, sleep-disordered breathing, severe hypothyroidism, myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barre syndrome and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of easy irritability and insomnia for the past 2 years. The patient's wife states that these episodes usually alternate with periods where her husband complains of feeling hopeless, low mood, and dejected. The patient denies using drugs, or consuming alcohol and states that he has been this way for as long as he remembers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient experiencing alternate periods of irritability and feeling dejected for a period greater than 2 years is cyclothymic disorder.

Cyclothymia is a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy for a minimum duration of at least 4 days.

The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

Alcohol abuse and other substance abuse are commonly seen in patients with cyclothymic disorder. These patients use these drugs to self-medicate or to achieve even further stimulation.

Mood stabilizers like lithium and antimanic drugs like sodium valproate are the first lines of treatment. Psychotherapy is a great way for patients to develop coping mechanisms to help with their mood swings. Patients often require life-long treatment.

Option A: Major depressive disorder usually presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, significant change in weight or appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, and feelings of worthlessness nearly every day. These symptoms are present for a minimum of 2 weeks. 

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. Episodes of mania/hypomania are not seen in this condition.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: Preconceptional use of which of the following leads to decreased incidence of neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Pre-conceptional use of folic acid reduces the incidence of neural tube defects.

Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.

Pregnant women are advised 60 mg of iron and 400 mcg of folic acid every day till term and during lactation for 3 months

questions.text: A patient presents with backache, night sweats, an evening increase in temperature, and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal an increase in CRP and ESR levels. An MRI is provided below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given spine MRI shows a patient with Pott's spine. The image depicts sagittal T1W (A) and T2W (B) images in a patient with spinal tuberculosis showing a well-defined, round lesion (arrow) with T1 hypointensity and T2 iso-hypointensity.

  • Pott's disease, also known as tuberculous spondylitis, refers to the vertebral body and intervertebral disc involvement in tuberculosis (TB).
  • The spine is the most frequent location of musculoskeletal TB, and commonly related symptoms are back pain and lower limb weakness/paraplegia.
  • The spine is involved due to hematogenous spread via the venous plexus of Batson.
  • There is usually a slow collapse of one or usually more vertebral bodies, which spreads underneath the longitudinal ligaments.
  • This results in an acute kyphotic or "gibbus" deformity.
  • This angulation, coupled with epidural granulation tissue and bony fragments, can lead to cord compression.

Radiographic Features:

Features include irregularity of both the endplate and anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies, with bone marrow edema and enhancement seen on MRI:

  • T1: hypointense marrow in adjacent vertebrae
  • T2: hyperintense marrow, disc, soft tissue infection
  • T1 C+ (Gd): marrow, subligamentous, discal, dural enhancement

The paraspinal collections are typically well-circumscribed, with fluid centres and well-defined enhancing margins.

Other options: 

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis: shows Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

Option B: Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. Radiography shows multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance.

Option C: Pyogenic spondylitis denotes infections impacting different components of the spine, including the vertebrae, intervertebral discs, paraspinal soft tissue, or epidural space. This umbrella term covers conditions such as vertebral osteomyelitis, spondylodiscitis, and epidural abscess.

questions.text: Alcoholic liver disease is suspected in a patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting. Which among the following makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely?
questions.solution:
An AST: ALT <2 makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely. 

In alcoholic liver disease(ALD), usually the AST: ALT is > 2:1. This is due to:

  • Deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise.

In ALD,

Option B: Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the decreased synthetic function of the liver.

Option C: Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Option D: Serum total bilirubin can be normal or elevated with advanced disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with symptoms of fatigue and headache. On further examination, he is found to have pallor, tingling, and numbness over his extremities. Peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia. Laboratory findings revealed methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes 15 years ago and has been taking metformin. Which of the following is most likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
A vitamin B12/cobalamin deficiency is most likely seen in him.

The given clinical features of peripheral neuropathy, peripheral smear finding of macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine, and history of metformin intake after being diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus indicate a vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Risk factors for B12 deficiency include gastric atrophy (pernicious anemia), terminal ileal disease, strict vegetarianism, acid-reducing drugs (e.g., H2 blockers), and prolonged use of metformin. The interference by metformin on calcium-dependent membrane action is responsible for vitamin B12-intrinsic factor malabsorption in the terminal ileum.

On examination, patients present anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord(SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B9(Folic acid) deficiency can also be seen in patients on prolonged use of metformin and can cause macrocytic anemia. Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid differentiates between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Folate deficiency results in:

  • Megaloblastic anemia 
  • Homocystenemia
  • Neural tube defects (spina bifida, Anencephaly) in the fetus.

Option C: A patient with pyridoxine / Vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and microcytic anemia.

Option D: A patient with thiamine / Vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with painful menses, pain during intercourse, and infertility. Per vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices with a normal-sized nulligravid uterus. A speculum exam reveals bluish-puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the cavity of the uterus. The three categories of endometriosis are:

  • Pelvic endometriosis
  • Ovarian endometriosis/Chocolate cyst
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis

Patients present with symptoms such as dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, lower abdominal pain, infertility, and menorrhagia.

Per speculum examination of these patients reveals bluish or blackish puckered spots in the posterior fornix that are tender to touch. The presence of these spots is pathognomic of endometriosis. Vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with a burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Epigastric pain with burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.

The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:

Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.

Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a history of oral ulcers, photosensitivity, joint pain, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is systemic lupus erythematosus(SLE).

SLE is an inflammatory autoimmune disorder associated with the presence of antinuclear antibodies. This disease is most commonly seen in women. Patients present with symptoms such as:

  • fever
  • anorexia
  • weight loss
  • alopecia
  • malar rash 
  • joint pains
  • photosensitivity
  • oral ulcers

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins will you prescribe for a patient on antitubercular therapy?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid (INH), which is a first-line anti-tuberculosis drug, inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase, resulting in pyridoxine deficiency and neuropathy. Prophylactic administration of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) 10 mg/day can prevent neuropathy from developing. 

10 mg daily suffices for prophylaxis but patients with evidence of vitamin B6 deficiency may require up to 50 mg daily.

Current WHO guidelines recommend routine substitution of pyridoxine to patients who are at risk of peripheral neuropathy, e.g., malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetics, HIV.

However, pyridoxine excess (acute intoxication or long-term use of large doses) is also found to cause peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with suspected acute leukemia shows the following characteristic finding. What is the structure marked by the arrow known as?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Auer rods, which are characteristically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Auer rods are clumps of azurophilic granular material that appear as elongated needles, in the cytoplasm of leukemic blasts.

They can be seen in the leukemic blasts of AML and acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient in the post-operative ward becomes confused and drowsy and has one episode of vomiting post-thyroidectomy. On examination, she has a temperature of 100 degrees F along with tremors of the hand. Laboratory reports reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels. The best drug for the immediate management of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with features of fever, central nervous system depression, vomiting, and elevated thyroid hormones following surgery is suggestive of thyroid storm. Propylthiouracil, which inhibits thyroid synthesis and also inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is the best drug for the immediate management of this case.

Thyroid storm/ Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones.

Causes:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration
  • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI (radioactive iodine) therapy

Features:

  • They present 12–24 hours after surgery with hyperpyrexia and severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures – rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
  • Thionamides like Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole are used. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis. Propylthiouracil also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Hence, PTU is the preferred drug in thyroid storm. However, the risk for severe liver injury and acute liver failure associated with PTU therapy makes either carbimazole or methimazole the first choice thionamides in patients with deranged liver function tests.
  • Lugol’s iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit the organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Glucocorticoids – reduce the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and controls the shock. 
  • Digoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.

*Note: As per the references, there are certain discrepancies over the drug of choice being an anti-thyroid drug (PTU) or a beta-blocker(Propranolol). However, as per the recent updates, PROPRANOLOL is primarily indicated in HYPERTHYROIDISM (not in thyroid crisis) because it has limited effect and slow onset for reducing serum T3 conversion. Additionally, in cases where deiodinase inhibition is significant (in cases of severe hyperthyroidism) like in THYROID CRISIS/ THYROTOXICOSIS an anti-thyroid drug is considered as the therapeutic drug (DOC), thus the answer to this MCQ is PTU and NOT PROPRANOLOL.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI therapy.

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Central nervous system agitation or depression
  • Cardiovascular and GI dysfunction, including hepatic failure

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion

Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

 Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage the cardiac failure.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
T2 image
Grey matter
Darker

White matter

CSF/ Fluids
Dark
Bright
Fat
White
Less white
Air

Cortical bone
Dark

Tendons and ligaments

Dark

Flowing blood and hemosiderin

questions.text: Identify the instrument used in thyroid surgery, shown below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image above is Joll retractor. Joll retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgery.

Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for herniorrhaphy, groin dissection for varicose veins, and femoral embolectomy.

Travers Retractor:

Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries:

Spencer Wells is a ratchet type forceps used extensively in surgery to clamp the artery before cutting it:

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue, bloating sensation, and weight loss of around 8 Kgs for the past 8 months. After a detailed workup, she was diagnosed with early gastric carcinoma. All of the following structures can be involved in this stage except:
questions.solution:
Early gastric cancer doesn't involve muscularis propria.

Gastric carcinoma can be classified as early gastric cancer and advanced gastric cancer.

  • Early gastric cancer involves mucosa, submucosa with or without lymph node involvement.
  • Advanced gastric cancer involves the muscularis layer, with or without adjacent structures.

questions.text: A 43-year-old obese man presents with loud chronic snoring and gasping episodes during sleep along with excessive daytime sleepiness. He is diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea. Which of the following would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?

choices.text: Implantable neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP).

Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms.

Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma In situ does not include:
questions.solution:
Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system.

The components of the Van Nuys Prognositic Index (VNPI) for grading ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) are as follows:

  • Patient’s age
  • Type of DCIS (histologic variant based on nuclear grade and presence of necrosis)
  • Presence of microcalcification
  • Extent of resection margin 
  • Size of tumor

Patients with a high score in this grading system benefit from radiotherapy after excision, whereas those with low-grade tumors, whose tumor is completely excised, need no further treatment.

 A score, ranging from 1 for lesions with the best prognosis to 3 for lesions with the worst prognosis, is given for each of the four prognostic predictors.  Scores range from 4 (least likely to recur) to 12 (most likely to recur).

Parameter Score 1 Score 2 Score 3
Tumor size (diamter in mm) < 15 16–40 greater or equal to 41
Margin width (in mm) >10 1–9 < 1
Pathologic Classification non-high grade, (nuclear grades 1 and 2) no necrosis non-high grade, (nucelar grades 1 and 2)with necrosis high grade (nuclear grade 3) with or without necrosis
Age  >60 40–60 <40

 

Note: The type of microcalcification seen on imaging, helps in determining the nuclear grade of DCIS.

  • Linear branching type of microcalcification is associated with high nuclear grade.
  • Fine granular type of microcalcification is associated with low nuclear grade.

This question was asked in the recent NEET exam. Since CA Breast is an high yield for any exam, proper knowledge of different criteria used in classifying the cancer is essential. Although hormone receptor is not part of the Van Nuys criteria, it is routinely assessed so as to facilitate good prognosis through hormone therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following does not indicate chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI)?
questions.solution:
Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) includes ischemic rest pain, ulceration and gangrene, and ABPI <0.4. Chronic limb ischemia usually does not produce paralysis.

Chronic arterial occlusion in the legs presents as intermittent claudication. This is a cramp-like pain that is brought on by walking some distance and relieved by rest, usually within 5 minutes. The pain of intermittent claudication is absent on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis), but is brought on as the patient walks some distance. The distance that the patient is able to walk comfortably — known as claudication distance — decreases as the disease progresses.

At some point, the perfusion to the leg is so severely compromised that there's inadequate oxygen delivery even at rest. This stage is known as rest pain. This kind of pain is worse on lying down or elevation of the foot, because the perfusion is further compromised when the effects of gravity are absent. Severe arterial insufficiency leads to tissue ulceration and gangrene. Patients with CLTI require urgent vascular intervention. Unlike acute limb ischemia, chronic limb ischemia usually does not result in paralysis and loss of sensation.

Quantitative assessment of peripheral arterial disease can be done with ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI). It is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery is the numerator, and the highest brachial systolic pressure is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >1.4:  Calcified vessels (chronic kidney disease, diabetes)
  • >0.9 to < 1.4: Normal
  • <0.9: Hemodynamically significant arterial lesion
  • <0.4 – CLTI

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the use of the contraceptive shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a cervical diaphragm or Dutch cap. It can be used by women having multiple sex partners.

Contraindications of cervical diaphragm usage:

  • Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele - accurate fitting is not possible
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection 
  • Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agent

It must be removed following intercourse as it can lead to toxic shock syndrome (TSS) if left in the vagina for a long period. TSS is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of heat stress?
questions.solution:
Effects of heat stress include heat stroke, heat hyperpyrexia, heat exhaustion, heat cramps and heat syncope.

Numbness is an effect of cold stress.

Heat Stress:

  • Heat stress is the load of heat that must be dissipated from the body if it is to remain in thermal equilibrium.
  • Factors that affect heat stress are metabolic rate, air temperature, humidity, air movement and radiant temperature.
  • Heat stress indices:
    • Equatorial comfort index
    • Heat stress index (HSI) 
HSI Thermal stress Work and effects
0 No thermal strain No work impairment
10 – 30 Moderate to mild heat strain Minimal work impairment
40 – 60 Severe heat strain Threat to health and greatly impaired work
70 – 90 Very severe heat strain Only few who are fit and acclimatized can sustain work
100 Upper limit of heat tolerance Only fit and acclimatized can sustain work, although with impairment
>100 Exceeds tolerable limits Varying degrees of heat stress and effects can pursue
  • Predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR)
    • Effects of heat stress include heat stroke, heat hyperpyrexia, heat exhaustion, heat cramps, and heat syncope.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure under general anesthesia, the patient suddenly develops hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia. Which of the following anesthetic agents is likely responsible for the patient developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient who developed hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia while undergoing surgery under general anesthesia is malignant hyperthermia. Inhaled general anesthetics such as desflurane are known to trigger this condition.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to the clinical finding being tested in the image below?
questions.solution:
By asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), the finding being elicited is clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, and aortic aneurysm, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to the hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of the epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than pharyngeal depth ratio.

The causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

questions.text: A woman presents at 33-weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery Doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts the reversal of end-diastolic flow (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. So the next step of management is the termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)

Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise - terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks.

Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death - terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age.

questions.text: An 8 month-old-child with developmental regression, was brought with repeated epileptic spasms upon arousal. The EEG showed irregular multifocal high-voltage spike and wave activity with a chaotic high-voltage slow background. What does the presentation associate with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and EEG interpretation referred to as hypsarrythmia is seen in infantile spasms (West syndrome).

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and consists of a triad of:

  • Infantile spasms (salaam attacks)
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrythmia (abnormal EEG)

West syndrome is best treated with

  • First-line agents: ACTH injections
  • Second-line agents: Vigabatrin
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came to OPD with a history of a lump in the right breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the right breast is 5 × 6 cm and has right-side interpectoral axillary lymphadenopathy. Interpectoral axillary lymph node belongs to ___________

choices.text: Level 1 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 3 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 2 group of axillary lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Interpectoral lymph nodes are classified under level 2 (deep) group of axillary lymph nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

  • Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor (anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular groups)
  • Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor (central and interpectoral groups)
  • Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to the pectoralis minor (apical/subclavicular group)

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of breast

The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into

  • The axillary lymph nodes (85%)
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Posterior intercostal/Interpectoral/ Rotter’s lymph nodes

The axillary nodes are arranged in the following groups:

Level I (Lymph nodes located lateral to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Lateral, along the axillary vein - drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior (external mammary group or pectoral group), along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast.(1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior (scapular group), along the subscapular vessels

Level II (Lymph nodes located superficial or deep to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Central, embedded in fat in the centre of the axilla- receive drainage from Level I groups

Level III (Lymph nodes located medial to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Apical (sub-clavicular group), which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferents of all the other axillary groups and drains in to subclavian lymphatic trunk.

Interpectoral (Rotters node) - a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.(Level II)

Internal mammary nodes drain posterior one-third of breast.

questions.text: Identify the birth defect.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts omphalocele.

Omphalocele is a midline abdominal defect and is covered by peritoneal or umbilical sac. Babies born with omphalocele should be thouroughly evaluated for other associated congenital anamolies like cardiac anamolies, neural tube defect and trisomies.

Management includes IV fluids, IV antibiotics, preservation of sac with a sterile saline gauze/bowel bag followed by surgical closure.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal

questions.text: A patient presents to the dermatology clinic complaining that a birthmark that was asymptomatic has now become pruritic with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic naevus (birthmark), suggestive of halo dermatitis. 

It is also known as Meyerson nevus. Histology shows a benign naevus surrounded by a dermal lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrate, with acanthosis, spongiosis, and parakeratosis.

The condition usually resolves spontaneously within a few months without involution of the nevus.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic superficial scaly dermatitis is a broad term that can encompass various skin conditions, including psoriasis and eczema. Both psoriasis and eczema can cause pruritic (itchy) and scaly skin.

Option B: Nummular dermatitis is a specific type of dermatitis characterized by coin-shaped or round plaques with scaling and itching. It often occurs on the limbs and trunk.

Option C: Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can present with various symptoms, including changes in the appearance of moles or birthmarks. Patients would have features like irregular borders, color variation, or rapid growth.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man sustained a road traffic accident and has a large wound on the thigh. After initial wound management, the plastic surgeon decides to cover the wound with a split skin graft. The order by which split skin graft survives is by_________
questions.solution:
Split skin graft survives by imbibition- inosculation-neovascularization.

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink colour of the skin.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with Cotrimoxazole.  He developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is  ________.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

Drugs that carry the risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD Deficiency:

Drugs

Antimalarials

Primaquine

Chloroquine

Dapsone/chlorproguanil

Sulphonamides/

sulphones

Sulfamethoxazole

Sulfasalazine

Sulfisoxazole

Antibacterial/

antibiotics

Cotrimoxazole

Ciprofloxacin

Chloramphenicol

Nalidixic acid

Norfloxacin

Nitrofurantoin

Others

Naphthalene

Methylene blue

Rasburicase

questions.text: When is cord clamping ideally done?
questions.solution:
As per the AMTSL guidelines, cord clamping is practised within 1-3 minutes of the delivery of the fetus.

Delayed cord clamping is done 30 to 60 seconds after birth in all the babies. This increases the amount of blood flowing from mother to baby which decreases the risk of anaemia in later life, improves hemodynamic stability, decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis,intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants, and also decreases the need for transfusions and inotropic support.

AMTSL guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonics (Oxytocin). Oxytocin (10 IU) is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Recent update: Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor in decreasing PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: A female patient, who is 6 months postpartum, presented with complaints of feeling low, anhedonia, and suicidal ideation since childbirth. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Postpartum depression is the most likely diagnosis in a postpartum woman with complaints of feeling low, anhedonia, and suicidal ideation. In such a patient, SSRIs such as Fluoxetine and Paroxetine are the preferred first-line drugs.

Postpartum depression falls under the ambit of postpartum mood disorders. Disorders such as postpartum blues and postpartum psychosis also fall under this category.

Postpartum depression occurs at least 4-6 months after childbirth or an abortion. It is characterized by symptoms such as loss of energy and appetite, insomnia, anhedonia, and in some cases, suicidal ideations.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as Fluoxetine and Paroxetine are preferred since they are effective and have fewer side effects. These drugs are also safe during breastfeeding.

Other options

Option A: Reassurance would be an appropriate next step in case the patient is suffering from postpartum blues.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a first-generation antipsychotic that is used in the management of postpartum psychosis

Option D: Lorazepam belongs to a class of drugs known as benzodiazepines that have no role in the management of postpartum mood disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of prerenal AKI?
questions.solution:
Non steroidal anti inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and ACE inhibitors cause prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). 

The use of NSAIDs causes reduced production of vasodilatory prostaglandins. This leads to decreased renal perfusion and glomerular capillary pressure. NSAIDs can also lead to acute interstitial nephritis, a cause of renal AKI. However, this is relatively uncommon.

ACE inhibitors cause inhibition of efferent arteriole vasoconstriction, leading to reduced renal perfusion.

Nephrotoxins like myeloma light chains, snake venom, myoglobin (due to rhabdomyolysis) cause acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This leads to renal or intrinsic AKI.

questions.text: An elderly man with a history of chain smoking is being evaluated for exertional dyspnea, and cough. His chest CT is given below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows emphysematous lungs, with reduced parenchymal markings and focal areas of low attenuation.

This represents the emphysematous destruction of the lung, indicative of hyperinflation.

Radiographic studies in COPD show:

  • Emphysematous bullae
  • A paucity of parenchymal markings
  • Hyperlucency suggests the presence of emphysema
  • Increased lung volumes and flattening of the diaphragm suggest hyperinflation

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with delayed puberty. Investigations reveal increased levels of gonadotropins. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased levels of gonadotropins pointing towards Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and Klinefelter's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal aneuploidy in males. Most of them have 47 XXY chromosomes. The diagnosis is rarely made before puberty, behavioral or psychiatric disorders may be apparent long before the defects in sexual development.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central):

Hypogonadism due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure):

Hypogonadism due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with mild ptosis and proximal lower limb weakness. Nerve conduction studies show incremental response following brief exercise. Further investigations reveal antibodies against presynaptic P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following malignancies is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength.

Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.

Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

questions.text: An 8 weeks pregnant woman, working in an industry consults a doctor.  According to the ESI act, what is the duration of maternity leave that she can get?

choices.text: 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery
26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

questions.solution:
According to ESI act, this pregnant woman is entitled to a leave of 26 weeks, starting 8 weeks preceding the expected date of delivery.

According to The Employees State Insurance Act and its amendments, pregnant ladies can receive benefits in cash for confinement/miscarriage or sickness arising out of the same or premature birth of a child or miscarriage. This includes maternity leave for

  • 26 weeks of which not more than 8 weeks shall be preceding the expected date of her delivery.
  • 6 weeks in case of miscarriage.
  • 30 days for sickness arising out of being in the family way, premature delivery or medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Women having 2 or more surviving children shall be allowed maternity leave of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks should be before the expected date of her delivery.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman from Assam presented with fever and chills recurring every 48 hours. On examination, she was conscious, oriented, and febrile. CBC, LFT, and RFT were normal. Peripheral smear revealed the following. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing crescent-shaped gametocytes are suggestive of uncomplicated falciparum malaria. As this woman is from a North-Eastern state, the drug regimen of choice is ACT-AL (artemisinin combination therapy): 

  • Artemether (20mg)
  • Lumefantrine (120mg)  

This regimen is followed in the North-Eastern states of India due to documented resistance to sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine in these areas. ACT-AL is contraindicated in:

  • 1st trimester of pregnancy
  • Children < 5 kg
