questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used to take samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for Pap smear.

Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction. Given below is the image of Ayre's spatula.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. A positive test requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation, but can be done at any other time as well. 24 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications.

Procedure:

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman who was brought to the ER with hemiparesis was found to have a lacunar infarction. What causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Lacunar infarcts, also called small vessel stroke, refer to infarction following atherothrombotic or lipohyalinotic occlusion of small penetrating arteries in the brain. These penetrating arteries arise from the stem of the middle cerebral artery, circle of Willis, and basilar and vertebral arteries.

The principal risk factors are hypertension and old age.

The image below shows two lacunar infarctions on a CT.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the clinical presentation of mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia is thymoma. 

Thymoma refers to the tumours of the thymic epithelial cells. They commonly occur in the anterior mediastinum. Clinical features can be chest pain, dyspnea, cough, or superior vena cava syndrome.

It is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like myasthenia gravis, pure red cell aplasia, or hypogammaglobulinemia. It is rarely associated with limbic encephalitis, hemolytic anaemia, aplastic anaemia, and other autoimmune conditions like Sjogren's syndrome.

Pure red cell aplasia: It is a marrow disorder where only erythroid progenitors are suppressed. The complete absence of red cell progenitors is seen in severe cases.

Hereditary causes include Diamond-Blackfan anaemia or congenital pure red cell aplasia.

Acquired causes:

  • Cancer
    • Thymoma
    • Lymphoid malignancies (eg. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, large granular lymphocytosis)
    • Paraneoplastic to solid tumors
  • Connective tissue disorders with immunologic abnormalities
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Viruses
    • Persistent B19 parvovirus, hepatitis, adult T cell leukemia virus, Epstein-Barr virus
  • Drugs
    • Phenytoin, azathioprine, chloramphenicol, procainamide, isoniazid
  • Multiple endocrine gland insufficiency
  • Antibodies to erythropoietin
  • Idiopathic

Other options:

Option B: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can cause pure red cell aplasia but it commonly presents as peripheral adenopathy rather than mediastinal mass.

Options C and D: Germ cell tumors and bronchogenic carcinoma are not commonly known to be associated with red cell aplasia.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding after accidentally spilling hydrofluoric acid over his hand. What is the preferred initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of hydrofluoric acid skin burns is with the application of calcium carbonate gel.

Immediate first aid to help prevent severe injuries from a chemical burn include:

  • Carefully remove the chemical and any contaminated clothing
    • Remove the chemical and contaminated clothing from contact with the skin and eyes
    • Do not wipe the skin as this may spread contamination
    • If the chemical is dry, brush it off the skin
    • Use gloves or other protective materials to cover hands and, if possible, carefully cut away clothing such as T-shirts, rather than pulling them off over the head
  • Rinse the affected area using as much clean water as possible
    • Rinse the affected area continuously with clean water as soon as possible
    • Try to make sure the water can run off the affected area without pooling on the skin
    • Only use water– do not rub or wipe the area

In very few cases initial management by lavage with water is not useful. Ex: Phosphorous used in some military devices and elemental sodium seen in laboratory explosions.

In hydrofluoric acid burns, initially, calcium gluconate gel is applied topically. Severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier’s blocks containing calcium gluconate 10 % gel. If the burn is with a concentration of greater than 50 %, then acute early excision is indicated due to the chance of hypocalcemia and arrhythmias. Split skin graft application to a hydrofluoric acid wound should be delayed and must not be done initially. 

Note - Although topical calcium gluconate is usually preferred, topical calcium carbonate gels may also be used for treating burns as they are also effective in providing calcium ions to complex the  free fluoride ions to prevent further toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the image given below
questions.solution:
The given vertex presentation is right occipitoanterior, where the occiput is occupying the right anterior quadrant of the pelvis.

Fetal position refers to the relationship of the fetal presenting part to the birth canal.

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease has multiple skip lesions in the intestine. Surgical resection of damaged areas is being planned. Removal of which part will cause steatorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ileal resection may lead to steatorrhoea.

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption that presents with steatorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding ARDS?
questions.solution:
ARDS is characterized by:

  • PCWP of ≤18 mmHg with no clinical evidence of increased left atrial pressure.
  • Decreased pulmonary compliance
  • Increased pulmonary artery pressure
  • Severe hypoxemia

questions.text: An intern attempts to insert a Foley catheter in an elderly male patient. However, in the first attempt, he meets resistance while advancing the catheter and fails at few more attempts with a smaller size catheter. Which of the following is the next best step?

choices.text: Attempt to pass a larger size catheter

questions.solution:
The next best step would be to examine the urethral anatomy using cystoscopy.

Cystoscopy is used to assess the urethra for size, strictures, false passage, or bladder neck stenosis. This facilitates the placement of a guidewire beyond any identified stricture over which a Councill catheter can be placed.

Other options

Option A: A suprapubic catheter is inserted only if all the attempts at urethral catheterization including flexible cystoscopy guidance are unsuccessful.

Option C: Attempting to pass a larger catheter in a patient who is suspected to have a stricture causes further trauma. However, a smaller bore catheter would be the appropriate choice.

Option D: An internal urethrotomy is a procedure that is done in cases where the urethral stricture is diagnosed. It uses an optical urethrotome to cut the fibrotic stricture under visual control.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Differences between single-exposure and multiple exposures epidemics are:

  Point source, single exposure Point source, multiple exposures 
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning from an event Sex worker infected with gonorrhoea, contaminated well water

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant is seen with a rash on his nose, cheek and forehead, as shown in the image below. On examination, they are noted to be pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Milia is the most probable diagnosis. This condition presents with small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over the nose, cheek, and forehead. They are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. 

Infantile milia may occasionally be associated with oral lesions on the gingivae or palate. Milia are more common in white children, but less frequent in children born prematurely or of low gestational weight. They resolve spontaneously without scarring.

 Other options:

Option A: Erythema toxicum presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base with eosinophil laden sterile lesions, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. It is a normal finding in many newborns. They are seen 1–3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week and resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Option B: Pustular melanosis is a benign transient condition that lasts for 2-3 days in newborns. It is seen predominantly in black neonates. The lesions are vesiculopustular eruption and have neutrophils.

Option C: Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Identify the phase of menstruation given below:
questions.solution:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of endometrium.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases.

 Features in proliferative phase/ follicular phase:

  • It begins when the regeneration of menstruating endometrium is complete and lasts until the 14th day of the menstrual cycle.
  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • The basal layer of the endometrium and functional layer become more defined.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiraled and extend through the endometrium.

Features in secretory phase/ luteal phase:

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day of the menstrual cycle and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • The epithelium shows subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity).
  • Characteristic corkscrew-shaped glands and edematous stroma.

The image below shows the secretory endometrium

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and hemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: A man underwent vasectomy recently.  The surgeon advises the patient to abstain from sexual activity for a certain period after the procedure before confirming the success of the vasectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding the duration of abstinence post-vasectomy?

choices.text: 3 months and after semen analysis is done
1 month and after semen analysis is done

questions.solution:
A patient who has undergone a vasectomy should abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and undergo a semen analysis afterwards.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally.

This procedure is done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided on both sides, disrupting the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and a skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure as semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods.

Hence, for this reason, it is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or 3 months are required to empty the stored semen. During this time, additional contraceptive measures should be used.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her paediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An atrial septal defect (ASD) is the most likely diagnosis due to the characteristic finding of the widely split second heart sound that is fixed during all phases of respiration.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.

Other options:

  • In ventricular septal defect (VSD) – Wide variable splitting of S2 which is masked by the pansystolic murmur.
  • In patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) – first sound is accentuated and S2 is narrowly or paradoxically split.
  • In coarctation of aorta – first sound is accentuated, S2 is normally split with a loud aortic component.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented with complaints of recurrent bilateral painless swelling over the parotid glands. FNAC done showed acinar cell hypertrophy without any inflammatory signs.  All of the following are associated with this condition except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and FNAC report of acinar hypertrophy are suggestive of sialadenosis. Hyperthyroidism is not associated with sialadenosis.

Sialosis (sialadenosis) is defined as an asymptomatic, non-inflammatory, non-neoplastic parenchymal salivary gland disease. It is accompanied by a persistent painless bilateral swelling of the salivary glands, most commonly involving the parotid glands. Most cases of sialadenosis are observed in patients between 40 to 70 years of age, and the salivary gland swellings are often soft and symmetrical. On FNAC, acinar cell hypertrophy is seen without any inflammatory signs.

Sialadenosis is associated with the following conditions:

  1. Nutritional disorders
    • Bulimia nervosa
    • Vitamin deficiency
  2. Endocrine disorders
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hypothyroidism
  3. Metabolic disorders
    • Obesity
    • Cirrhosis
    • Malabsorption
  4. Autoimmune disorders 
    • Sjögren disease 
  5. Drug-induced 
    • Valproic acid
    • Thiourea
  6. Pregnancy
  7. Alcoholism

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with progressive swelling of his right wrist associated with a dull aching pain. The orthopedician elicits tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is osteoclastoma/giant cell tumor.

Osteoclastoma is a bone tumour with varying growth potential. It can be either benign/malignant, though it is more commonly benign. It is seen in patients who are 20-40 years of age. The commonly affected sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the distal end of the radius.

Patients present with swelling and vague pain. Pathological fractures may also be seen. On examination, firm palpation can elicit tenderness. 

Radiologically, soap bubble appearance is seen due to interspersed lytic lesions and bone remnants. Intralesional curettage of the tumour is the common approach to management.

Other options

Option A: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour arising from the cartilage cells. It may arise in any bone but is common in flat bones such as the scapula, pelvis, and ribs.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a highly malignant primary bone tumor. Common sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the upper end of the humerus. Patients present with a history of pain followed by swelling. Radiologically, periosteal reaction, sunburst appearance, and Codman's triangle can be seen. The characteristic sunburst appearance can be seen below.

Option D: Osteochondroma is a common benign tumour of the bone. The tumour stops enlarging in size once there is a cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is usually seen in adolescents who present with painless swelling around a joint, usually the knee. X-ray shows a well-defined exostosis as shown below.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness for weeks. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and jugular venous pressure showed prominent x and y descent. The chest radiograph is seen below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing calcification of the pericardium are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis is a condition in which granulation tissue formation in the pericardium results in loss of pericardial elasticity leading to restricted ventricular filling. It is usually a chronic condition.

The leading cause worldwide is tuberculosis. Other common causes include viral infections, SLE and idiopathic. Patients who have undergone cardiac surgery or radiation therapy are also at an increased risk of developing this condition.

Clinically patients present with symptoms such as dyspnea, orthopnea and fatigue. On physical examination, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is usually elevated with a prominent x and y descent. JVP does not decrease with inspiration, and this is known as Kussmaul's sign. 

ECHO is used to make a diagnosis and patients may demonstrate pericardial calcification on chest radiographs. Pericardiectomy is the only definitive management.

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presents with elevated 24-hour urinary Metanephrines. What is the next best step in the clinical management of this patient?

choices.text: Imaging study with an MRI scan
Medical pre-treatment with phenoxybenzamine followed by laparoscopic resection
Imaging study with a contrast CT scan

questions.solution:
Here, the elevated urinary metanephrines point towards the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, and the next step is an MRI to localize the site of the tumor.

The stepwise approach to the clinical vignette is as follows: 

Step 1: Diagnosis based on the features - The patient is suffering from pheochromocytoma as inferred from the elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine levels. 

Step 2: Localising the pathology - Detected by imaging studies, preferrably MRI.

MRI is preferred for localization of pathologies because contrast media used for CT scans can provoke paroxysms. Also, with the MRI, exposure to radiation is reduced in the case of children and pregnant women. Classically, pheochromocytomas show a ‘Swiss cheese’ configuration.

Step 3: Treating the pathology - Laparoscopic resection is now a routine in the treatment of pheochromocytoma. An α-adrenoreceptor blocker (phenoxybenzamine) is used pre-operatively to block excess catecholamine and thereby, the effects of its consequences during surgery.

Other options:

Option D: 123 Iodine-MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is essential for the detection of multiple extra-adrenal tumours and metastases, but PET scan using FDG or DOPA is more sensitive in detecting metastatic foci.

questions.text: Walls of the CT scanner rooms are coated with _____
questions.solution:
• Lead is the most common agent used in modern construction to offer radiation shielding.
  • Lead aprons are used to safeguard from scattered radiation. Thickness is 0.5 mm (0.25 – 0.5 mm).
  • TLD badge (Thermoluminescent dosimeter) is used to monitor radiation dose in India. It is made up of Lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

questions.text: Pregnancy is a pro-coagulant state. Which of the following is not true about hematological changes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Clotting factor XIII decreases during pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Haematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13).
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
  • Anticoagulants Protein C, Protein S and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
  • The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and women are asymptomatic).

questions.text: According to the Denis classification, which of the following is not included in the middle column of the spine?

choices.text: Posterior part of the vertebral body
Posterior part of the vertebral disc

questions.solution:
According to the Denis three-column theory, the posterior part of the pedicles is included in the posterior column of the spine, not in the middle column.

The 3 columns of the spine according to Denis classification are depicted in the image below.

The Denis classification is used to describe spinal injuries and classify them as stable or unstable. As per this system, any injury involving 2 columns or more is classified as unstable. Unstable injuries require surgical fixation.

The current AO/ASIF classification that replaced Denis classification reverts back to the previously prevalent two-column theory. It divides the spine as follows:

  • Anterior column: vertebral body and disc
  • Posterior column: pedicles, laminae, facets and posterior ligamentous complex

questions.text: Which of the following gases is stored in the given cylinder?
questions.solution:
Blue cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide.

Maximum pressure in the nitrous oxide cylinder is around 745 psig.

Critical temperature of nitrous oxide is 36.5oC, hence it is present in liquid form at room temperature.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: 50 year old hypothyroid female presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues,most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Hard “woody” thyroid gland is a feature of Riedel’s thyroiditis.

Riedel’s thyroiditis:

  • Invasive fibrous thyroiditis which is of autoimmune origin.
  • Characterised  by replacement of thyroid gland tissue with Fibrous tissue and may also invade  adjacent tissues.
  • The disease occurs predominantly in women between the ages of 30 and 60 years old.
  • It typically presents as a painless, hard anterior neck mass.
  • It progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression, including dysphagia, dyspnea, choking, and hoarseness.
  • Patients may present with symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue.
  • Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues.
  • The diagnosis needs to be confirmed by open thyroid biopsy, because the firm and fibrous nature of the gland renders FNAB inadequate.

Treatment includes long-term glucocorticoids to decrease the inflammation being first choice. Tamoxifen has also been used. Surgery is indicated to relieve obstruction.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) - It is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY): It is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill-health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state less than full health

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index

[HDI]

 India currently ranks 132 (HDI is 0.633) on the 2021-2022 Human developmental Index.

questions.text: A  patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped lesion that crosses suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Crescent-like distribution around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Crescent-shaped hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: Radical neck dissection spares which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle. 

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of the following structures:

  • All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups, extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally
  • All lymph nodes from Levels I through to V
  • Spinal accessory nerve
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Tail of parotid
  • Submandibular gland

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her otherwise healthy neonate with the lesion show in image. What would you do?

choices.text: Low dose broad spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis

questions.solution:
Reassure the mother that it is benign as the image shows Epstein Pearls.

Epstein Pearls

  • Are nests of epithelial cells.
  • Appear as whitish/yellowish spots on the hard palate.
  • It may also occur over the tip of Prepuce at 6 o'clock position.
  • Usually, resolve in 3 months.

 No intervention is necessary as it resolves spontaneously and is a benign condition.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. 

If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability.

Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

Option D:  The external oblique flap is a type of myocutaneous flap used in reconstructive surgery

DIEP flap, TRAM flap, and LD flap are autogenous tissues used in breast reconstruction.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of chronic scaly plaques over the extensor surface associated with pruritus. On examination, the patient's nails demonstrate subungual hyperkeratosis and distal onycholysis as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is psoriasis. The pruritic scaly lesions, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis are nail findings seen in patients with psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Patients commonly present with red, scaly plaques over the extensor surfaces and the scalp, associated with pruritus.

Nail findings are commonly seen across all types of psoriasis. Patients present with pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. In the case of nail bed involvement subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis can be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. Nail involvement includes exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depression. This is due to nail plate thinning. If the nail bed is involved, it can result in hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis. In some cases, pterygium unguis can be seen due to adhesion between the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed.

Option C - Atopic dermatitis presents with itchy erythematous papules/papulo-vesicles in flexural regions. Patients usually have a history of other autoimmune diseases.

Option D - Alopecia areata is a condition that results in non-scarring hair loss. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails, roughening of the nail plate (trachyonychia), or atrophic dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: An 84-year-old man has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following can be used to assess his cerebral perfusion?
questions.solution:
Tc HMPAO (technetium-99m hexamethyl propylenamine oxime) SPECT is used for the assessment of cerebral perfusion. In Alzheimer's disease, it shows reduced perfusion of the temporoparietal region.

Option B: In-111 (Indium) DTPA is injected intrathecally to assess CSF flow.

Option C: Tc-99m (Technetium) MIBI is used for parathyroid scintigraphy.

Option D: Tl-201 (Thallium) is used in myocardial perfusion scanning.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with an injured femoral artery following a stab injury to the right thigh. Which of the following suture material would be ideal for the repair of the artery?
questions.solution:
Polypropylene is the ideal suture material to repair the femoral artery.

The vascular anastomosis requires an accurate and watertight closure. Hence it requires a non-absorbable material that can provide tensile strength for a longer period. In addition, the material should be non-braided to avoid platelet adherence to the suture material. Hence, polypropylene which is a non-absorbable monofilament is used for vascular anastomoses.

questions.text: Which sampling method is used for assessing the immunization status of children under the immunization program?
questions.solution:
Cluster sampling is the method of sampling done in immunization programs for assessing the immunization status of children.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • A random is defined by the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.
  • For example, picking 4 random cards from a bag full of cards.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • For example, if a researcher wants to do a study on 100 doctors working in hospitals in Bangalore, he would select a cluster of 10 hospitals (clusters) and then take 10 doctors from each hospital as part his sample.
  • This is usually done when large scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 10th person to be admitted to the hospital can be selected or every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: Red degeneration of fibroid was diagnosed in a pregnant woman who presented with an acute abdomen. How will you treat this patient___
questions.solution: Red degeneration is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.

questions.text: A young male patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with complaints of breathing difficulty. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated with a prominent x descent and an absent y descent. While recording the patient's blood pressure, a significant drop in systolic pressure during inspiration is noted. Auscultation revealed absent heart sounds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is a condition caused to accumulation of the fluid in the pericardial space causing significant obstruction to the inflow of blood into the cardiac ventricles.

The most common causes of tamponade are pericarditis, tuberculosis, and bleeding into the pericardial space secondary to trauma/cardiac surgery.

The three main features associated with cardiac tamponade are hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distension. These features constitute Beck's triad. 

Jugular venous pulse(JVP) demonstrates a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.

Paradoxical pulse is another feature seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and is characterized by a significant decline (>10 mm Hg) in arterial pressure during inspiration.

Other options:

  • While constrictive pericarditis can also lead to elevated jugular venous pressure, it typically does not cause the classic physical findings associated with cardiac tamponade, such as pulsus paradoxus (significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration) and the absence of heart sounds. Patients with constrictive pericarditis (option A) demonstrate a prominent y descent.
  • The physical exam findings in this case, including elevated jugular venous pressure and pulsus paradoxus, are not typically associated with a myocardial infarction. Additionally, absent heart sounds are not a characteristic finding of myocardial infarction.
  • While heart failure can result in elevated jugular venous pressure, the physical exam findings, including pulsus paradoxus, absent heart sounds, and prominent x descent with an absent y descent, are not specific to cardiac failure and are more indicative of cardiac tamponade in this context.

questions.text: All of the following drugs can be used in the management of hypertension in pregnancy except for?
questions.solution:
Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Enalapril is an ACE-Inhibitor which is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential teratogenic side effects like renal dysplasia and renal failure.

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as bony malformations, persistent patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), respiratory distress syndrome, limb contracture, etc.

Choice of anti-hypertensives in pregnancy:

Pregnancy-induced hypertension/pre-eclampsia / severe pre-eclampsia Labetalol
Acute hypertension/ Hypertensive crisis IV labetalol, nifedipine, hydralazine
Chronic hypertension in pregnancy Labetalol > methyl dopa.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include:

  • ACE inhibitors.
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers.
  • Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in congestive cardiac failure).
  • Reserpine.
  • Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension).
  • Diazoxide.

questions.text: A boy says he hates chocolates after his parents scolded him for eating too much of it. The defence mechanism operating here is  _______________
questions.solution:
Reaction formation is the defense mechanism operating here. It converts unacceptable impulses into acceptable ones before they enter consciousness. Here, the unacceptable impulse is the boy’s fondness for chocolate, which is turned into dislike to appease his parents.

Suppression is the conscious act of avoiding unpleasant thoughts and impulses. For example, a student trying to avoid thoughts about exams.

Asceticism means giving up on life’s pleasures. The person derives gratification from giving up pleasures. For example, a rich man giving away everything he owns and going on a pilgrimage.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.
Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.
Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy done for a patient with a chronic painless facial swelling is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this tumor?

choices.text: This tumor has no malignant potential
Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice
Histology shows a double layer of epithelial cells with dense lymphoid stroma
It is the most common unilateral benign tumor of the parotid gland

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Warthin’s tumor. These tumors appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans because of the high mitochondrial content in oncocytes that incorporate technetium-99m. The most common benign tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

Warthin’s tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum usually presents as a unilateral tumor.  It is usually seen in the lower poles of the parotid and is commonly associated with smoking. It occurs most often in elderly males. It has no malignant potential.   

Histology shows tumor cells lined by a double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on the dense lymphoid stroma. FNAC is the preferred investigation. Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice.

Note: Both pleomorphic adenoma and Warthin's tumors commonly present as unilateral tumors. A bilateral presentation is usually rare. However in rare cases, if there is a bilateral benign salivary tumor, the tumor is most likely to be a Warthin's tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not considered in the Silverman Anderson score to assess the newborn?
questions.solution:
Cyanosis is not a criterion used to assess the newborn in the Silverman Anderson score which is used to assess and monitor respiratory distress in newborns and is more suited for preterms with hyaline membrane disease.  Score >6 indicates impending respiratory failure

Silverman Anderson score:

    Score    0      1       2

Upper chest retraction

(Chest movement)

 Synchronized Lag on inspiration See-saw

Lower chest retraction

(Intercostal retraction)

 None Just visible Marked
Xiphoid    retraction None Just visible Marked
Nasal dilatation None Minimal Marked
Grunt None Stethoscope Naked ear

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow, and his urine appears pale straw. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase.

Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 hours and/or treatment with phototherapy without cessation of breastfeeding. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Other options: 

Option A and D: Biliary atresia and Neonatal cholestasis have conjugated bilirubinemia.

Option C: Erythroblastosis foetalis has unconjugated bilirubinemia and it is seen in the first 24 hours of life.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain. His BP was found to be 160/90 mm Hg. Further evaluation with CT was done and the finding is shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the clinical features of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

ADPDK is characterized by the progressive formation of epithelial-lined cysts in the bilateral kidneys that ultimately leads to the loss of normal functioning renal tissue. Many patients do not have any symptoms until they are 40-50 years of age. The clinical manifestations include flank pain, hematuria (from cyst rupture), and hypertension due to increased Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) activation.

Extrarenal manifestations of the disease include benign hepatic cysts, intracranial aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, and colonic diverticula.

Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. The nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 

Other options:

Option A and C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) and acute pyelonephritis, show striated nephrogram on CT nephrography (as shown below).

Option D: Renal angiomyolipoma show well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue on CT imaging.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure
  • The commonest cause of abdominal mass in children

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Fever in systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA) is characteristically __________.
questions.solution:
Fever in systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA) is characteristically quotidian fever.

Systemic JIA is characterized by

  • Fever of at least 2 weeks; quotidian fever—fever that rises to 39°C (102.2°F) once a day and returns to 37°C (98.6°F) between fever peaks
  • Arthritis in 1 or more joints
  • Rash: Evanescent, salmon-colored, and non-pruritic
  • Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly, and/or lymphadenopathy
  • Serositis

Other options

Continuous Fever: The temperature remains elevated above normal without touching the baseline and the fluctuation does not exceed 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in the cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days, e.g. Plasmodium vivax, ovale, falciparum.

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days, e.g. Plasmodium malariae.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed fever, malaise, and anorexia a month after undergoing liver transplantation. On evaluation, he has leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and deranged liver function tests. Which of the following organisms is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-solid organ transplant infection most likely due to cytomegalovirus(CMV). It is the most common cause of post-solid organ transplants in India. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), herpes, and varicella are also known to cause infection post-solid organ transplantation but to a lesser extent.

CMV disease in recipients can present with fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, malaise, and arthralgia. They usually present within 1-4 months after transplant. The diagnosis of CMV infection is established by nucleic acid testing (NAT) using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Management includes the use of anti-viral drugs like ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir and intravenous immunoglobulins.

questions.text: What is Robert's sign?
questions.solution:
Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the fetal heart, seen in fetal demise in utero.

It may appear as early as 12 hours but difficult to interpret.

 Other sonographic signs:

  • Absent fetal Heartbeat
  • Absent fetal movements
  • Occasional findings
    • Overlapping of skull bones Spalding's sign 
    • Gross distortion of fetal anatomy (Maceration)
    • Soft tissue edema: skin >5 mm
    • Echogenic amniotic fluid  (fetal demise fragments)

Robert's sign

Spaldings sign

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image is magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing choline peak, which is diagnostic of glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information.

Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in tumors. Choline is an important component of the cell membranes. 

 

Image: The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

questions.text: A child can copy circle, but he cannot copy a square. If the development of this child is normal, at this age,  he should be able to ___________
questions.solution:
Normally, a child is able to copy a circle at 3 years and a square at 4 years. This child is a 3-year-old, and he should be able to know his name and gender.

  • A child is able to tell a story at 4 years.
  • Asks meaning of words at 5 years.
  • A child can skip at 5 years.

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks, draws a line
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, copies a circle, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: Nesbitt procedure is used for _____.
questions.solution:
The most common procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbitt procedure.

This corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction and pain on erection.

Other options:

Option B: Marion's disease is a condition where hypertrophy of internal sphincter leads to bladder outlet obstruction.

Option C: Priapism means persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours and it is a surgical emergency (in case of ischemic priapism).

Option D: Erectile dysfunction is consistent or recurrent inability to attain and/or maintain a penile erection sufficient for sexual satisfaction, which must persist for a minimum duration of 3 months for clinical diagnosis, except in cases of trauma or surgically-induced erectile dysfunction where the diagnosis can be made immediately.

questions.text: A patient developed a loss of sensation over the root of the penis, following laparoscopic hernia surgery. Injury to which of the following causes this?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation at the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

The iliohypogastric nerve (Option B) carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (Option C) results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh (Option D) is a sensory branch of the femoral nerve. Injury to this nerve leads to loss of sensations over the areas supplied by this nerve, which include anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a known history of diabetes came with a wound on his foot. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The given picture showing an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point is most likely that of a trophic ulcer/neuropathic ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.

Features of a neuropathic ulcer include

  • Painless ulcer
  • Punched out ulcer with regular margins
  • Often located on the plantar surface of the foot
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses 
  Ischemic/Arterial Ulcer Venous Ulcer Neuropathic Ulcer  Tuberculous Ulcer   
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease- mainly atherosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans, cervical rib, Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits Lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot, toes Neck, axilla, and groin
Characteristics

Deep, penetrates the deep fascia exposing the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone.

The ulcer is painful, tender, and hyperaesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, and painless, the floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. Punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, undermined; pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged, usually, the vertical group and the ulcer is recurrent; forms again after healing Dry, cracked, insensate Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, matted

 

Option A: The following is an image of a venous ulcer.

Option B: The following is an image of a malignant ulcer (squamous cell carcinoma).

Option C: The following is an image of an arterial ulcer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics.

A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.

Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation.

Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance for bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis is the sequela of inadequately treated acute prostatitis.
Diagnosis includes: 

  • Three-glass urine test - Prostatic thread in the first glass(initial sample) indicates prostatitis.
  • Digital rectal examination - Prostate may be normal, boggy, or tender.
  • Prostatic fluid examination - post-prostatic massage fluid shows pus cells and bacteria.

questions.text: Epithelial cells demonstrate the highest cornification index during which of the following phases of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
The cornification index is the percentage of cornified cells and is used to assess estrogen activity. The cornification index is highest during the late proliferative phase.

During the late proliferative phase, there is maximal estrogen activity and the cornification index is highest during this period.

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with infertility and menstrual abnormalities. Hysterosalpingogram was done to study the patency of fallopian tubes and the following finding is seen. What is the most probable causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

All the other options - N. gonorrhoea, C. trachomatis, and Mycoplasma hominis are causative agents for pelvic inflammatory disease.

Other hysterosalpingography features of genital tuberculosis are given below:

Image below shows "Pipe stem" or "Lead pipe" appearance. There is absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe like appearance show fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

Image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows multiple small diverticular like appearance surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration giving the tubal outline a Rosette-like appearance (" Tufted tube" )

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: During your ICU rotations, you see a  patient being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as a first step in airway management. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

Mask ventilation is not preferred in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.

The following image shows the parts of a self-inflating bag and mask apparatus with a reservoir bag.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her HbA1c level at diagnosis is 11.1%. What is the initial drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. 

Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases:

  • Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents
  • HbA1c > 9% at diagnosis

In patients with HbA1c < 9%, metformin is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with pain abdomen. On per abdominal examination, there is guarding and rigidity. During laparotomy, a diverticular perforation is seen with purulent peritonitis.  What is the Hinchey's stage in this case?
questions.solution:
Purulent peritonitis belongs to stage 3 in the Hinchey classification.

Hinchey classification is the most commonly used classification for the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. 

Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis.

Stage 1

Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: 33 yr old female with fever, weight loss, elevated levels of ACE levels presented with chest X-ray as below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with elevated ACE levels and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis.

Depending on the stage of sarcoidosis radiological features can range from a normal chest radiograph to pulmonary fibrosis.

Stage 0: Normal chest radiograph.

Stage I: Hilar or mediastinal nodal enlargement only.

Stage II: Nodal enlargement and parenchymal disease.

Stage III: Parenchymal disease only.

Stage IV: End-stage lung (pulmonary fibrosis)

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.solution:
Bilateral hydrosalpinx is observed in the given image of hysterosalpingogram.

Hydrosalpinx is often bilateral and occurs following acute salpingitis. The tubes are retort shaped due to dilatation of the ampulla and filled with a clear fluid. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during hysterosalpingography. 

Retort shaped hydrosalpinx:

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought to the outpatient department with a deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the preferred first-line conservative management?
questions.solution:
The first line of conservative management of the condition in the given image, congenital talipes equino varus deformity (CTEV), is manipulation and cast by Ponsetti's method.

CTEV is a congenital deformity of the foot. In a full-blown deformity, the foot is in equinus, the entire hindfoot is in varus and the mid and forefoot are adducted and supinated. Clinically this appears as a foot that's twisted and turned inwards.

In patients with CTEV, the skin and soft tissues of the calf and the medial side of the foot are underdeveloped. If CTEV is not managed appropriately then these changes become permanent.

The first line of conservative management in a child with CTEV is Ponsetti's method. In this method, the three main deformities of CTEV are collected in the following order.

  • Cavus - The first metatarsal is elevated to create a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot.
  • Adduction- The forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals which rotates and everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination
  • Equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators
